title: Kambo (drug) - Wikipedia
cleaned_text: known as vacina-do-sapo, or sapo (from "sapo", [lit.](/wiki/Literal_translation) meaning "toad"), is the dried skin secretions of the [kambô](/wiki/Phyllomedusa_bicolor), a species of frog, used as a transdermal medicine. No scientific evidence supports its effectiveness. Kambo is usually used in a group setting, called a Kambo circle or Kambo ceremony. The effects on humans usually include [tachycardia](/wiki/Tachycardia), [nausea](/wiki/Nausea), [vomiting](/wiki/Vomiting), and [diarrhea](/wiki/Diarrhoea), however, a meta-review of 50 studies in which 11 cases of acute intoxication were examined found that extreme cases may include [psychosis](/wiki/Psychosis) (occasionally severe), [SIADH](/wiki/SIADH), kidney damage (including acute renal including [toxic hepatitis](/wiki/Toxic_hepatitis), [dermatomyositis](/wiki/Dermatomyositis), [esophageal rupture](/wiki/Esophageal_rupture), these is limited. [[1]](#cite_note-JVATITD2014-1) [[2]](#cite_note-DalyCaceres1992-2) [[3]](#cite_note-ForensicScience2019-3) Kambo, which originated as a [folk medicine](/wiki/Folk_medicine) practice among [the Amazon](/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_the_Amazon) indigenous peoples, is also administered as an [alternative medicine](/wiki/Alternative_medicine) treatment in the West, often as a [pseudoscientific](/wiki/Pseudoscience) cleanse or [detox](/wiki/Detoxification_(alternative_medicine)). The ceremony involves burning an arm or leg and applying the kambo secretion directly to the burn. Promoters claim that kambo helps with several illnesses or injuries, but there is no [scientific evidence](/wiki/Scientific_evidence) that it is an effective treatment. [[4]](#cite_note-Derma2019-4) [[5]](#cite_note-TheGuardian2021-5) [[6]](#cite_note-ABCNewsMay2023-6) [[a]](#cite_note-longnote-7) It seems to be particularly dangerous to take a kambo with large quantities of water. Doing that is associated with [SIADH](/wiki/SIADH) and severe electrolyte imbalances: changes in plasma and urine osmolarity, [hypokalemia](/wiki/Hypokalemia), [hypomagnesemia](/wiki/Hypomagnesemia) and [hypophosphatemia](/wiki/Hypophosphatemia). [Naloxone](/wiki/Naloxone) is under study as a possible antidote; hospital treatment also includes medicines to protect organs from damage and restore electrolyte function. [[7]](#cite_note-SaccoZibettiBonetta2022-8) Common terms[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Kambo_(drug)&action=edit§ion=1)] - [Noke Kuin](/wiki/Huni_Kuin)(formerly Katukina) [[8]](#cite_note-Lima2000-01-9) - Dow kiet, name of [Phyllomedusa bicolor](/wiki/Phyllomedusa_bicolor), an [Amazonian](/wiki/Amazon_rainforest) tree frog, also known as the blue-and-yellow frog, bicolored tree-frog, giant monkey frog, giant leaf frog, or waxy-monkey tree frog. "Sapo" means "toad" in Spanish and Portuguese. [[1]](#cite_note-JVATITD2014-1) The frog is an anuran amphibian that inhabits the Amazon and [Orinoco](/wiki/Orinoco) basins in [South America](/wiki/South_America). [[11]](#cite_note-AmphibiaWeb2015-12) History[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Kambo_(drug)&action=edit§ion=2)] Natives who indigenous groups in the southeast on the use of kambo in traditional [Noke Kuin](/wiki/Huni_Kuin) medicine in the region of the state of [Acre](/wiki/Acre_(state)), in the [Brazilian Amazon](/wiki/Brazilian_Amazon). [[13]](#cite_note-tellus2014-14) Since the mid-20th-century, kambo has also been practiced in urban regions of Brazil. [[14]](#cite_note-SilvaMonteiro2019-15) [[12]](#cite_note-LimaLabate2007-13) In 2004, [Brazil](/wiki/Brazil) banned the sale and marketing of kambo. [[15]](#cite_note-BBCMundo2016-16) Import is illegal in [Chile](/wiki/Chile). [[16]](#cite_note-LaNancion2019-17) Outside of South America, it first became known as an [alternative therapy](/wiki/Alternative_medicine) in the late 2010s. [[17]](#cite_note-SBSnov2019-18) In 2021 the [Therapeutic Goods Administration](/wiki/Therapeutic_Goods_Administration) of Australia (TGA) banned the use of Kambo in Australia and classified it as a schedule 10 [poison](/wiki/Poison). It is listed in the category for "substances of such danger to health as to warrant prohibition of sale, supply and use". [[5]](#cite_note-TheGuardian2021-5) [[a]](#cite_note-longnote-7) Indigenous use[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Kambo_(drug)&action=edit§ion=3)] To collect the secretions from the frog's body, first, the frog has to be caught. A practitioner will tie the frog to four sticks placed in the ground with its limbs completely stretched. The pulling causes the frog to become stressed enough to activate its defense mechanism and secrete a substance containing peptides from its skin. [[18]](#cite_note-ABCnewsmarch2017-19) After obtaining secretions, the frog goes back into the wild. The secretions are then left to dry. [[18]](#cite_note-ABCnewsmarch2017-19) Small burns are created on the skin, and a small dose of the frog secretions applied to the open wounds. [[18]](#cite_note-ABCnewsmarch2017-19) In native practice, the secretions are removed from the wounds after 15 to 20 minutes, ending the acute symptoms. [[4]](#cite_note-Derma2019-4) Traditional practitioners claim that it aids [fertility](/wiki/Fertility), cleanses the body and soul, increases strength, and brings good luck to hunts, though there is no evidence for these claims. [[14]](#cite_note-SilvaMonteiro2019-15) [[19]](#cite_note-MontrealGazettesept2019-20) It is used by natives to who attempt to expel "panema" (bad spirit) and to [induce abortions](/wiki/Abortifacient). [[4]](#cite_note-Derma2019-4) The secretions are also commonly used in people who suffer from tikish or laziness, a condition perceived as unfavorable by the Noke Kuin as the person stops participating socially. [[20]](#cite_note-Lima2000-02-21) Joaquim Luz, a Yamanawa leader, criticized commercial sales and kambo's use without the preparation or permission of indigenous peoples, saying that the toxin users are at risk of death. [[15]](#cite_note-BBCMundo2016-16) Other native groups have also expressed concerns. [[14]](#cite_note-SilvaMonteiro2019-15) [[12]](#cite_note-LimaLabate2007-13) Non-indigenous use[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Kambo_(drug)&action=edit§ion=4)] Outside South America, a kambo ceremony can involve just two people, the practitioner, the participant, or many participants at once, which is known as a kambo circle. Participants are encouraged to bring plenty of water, a towel, and a bucket. [[17]](#cite_note-SBSnov2019-18) There are usually [yoga mats](/wiki/Yoga_mat) on the floor and the ceremony room, which is often the practitioner's living room, is heavily [incensed](/wiki/Incense). [[17]](#cite_note-SBSnov2019-18) During the ceremony, the participant's skin is deliberately burnt multiple times, usually on the upper arm or leg, by the practitioner using a [smoldering](/wiki/Smouldering) stick or vine. [[18]](#cite_note-ABCnewsmarch2017-19) The practitioner uses saliva or water to reconstitute the frog secretions and place it on top of the burnt skin. [[18]](#cite_note-ABCnewsmarch2017-19) Participants may be encouraged to shout "Viva" whenever one of them vomits into their bucket. [[21]](#cite_note-ABCNewssept2018-22) Short-term effects include violent nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, [edema](/wiki/Edema) (swelling) of the face, headaches, and [tachycardia](/wiki/Tachycardia). The secretions seem to be [vasoactive](/wiki/Vasoactive) (affecting the circulation), explaining why they are absorbed rapidly. [[4]](#cite_note-Derma2019-4) Intoxication may occur immediately or within hours. [[7]](#cite_note-SaccoZibettiBonetta2022-8) Medical claims[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Kambo_(drug)&action=edit§ion=5)] Non-indigenous users and practitioners of kambo claim that the alternative medicine helps with a wide variety of issues and conditions. These claims include treating [addiction](/wiki/Addiction), energy and physical strength, [[19]](#cite_note-MontrealGazettesept2019-20) [[21]](#cite_note-ABCNewssept2018-22) and improving mental clarity. [[21]](#cite_note-ABCNewssept2018-22) It is also claimed that kambo removes [negative energy](/wiki/Energy_(esotericism)). [[17]](#cite_note-SBSnov2019-18) [[19]](#cite_note-MontrealGazettesept2019-20) The causal role of kambo in positive outcomes is not proven. [[23]](#cite_note-HemaSphere2021-24) There is no solid medical evidence on how the frog toxins work, whether they are useful for treating anything, and whether they can be used safely: no [clinical trials](/wiki/Clinical_trial) have tested them on humans, as of November 2019 [[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kambo_(drug)&action=edit). [[4]](#cite_note-Derma2019-4) Reports of adverse effects are numerous, including for use with experienced guidance. [[4]](#cite_note-Derma2019-4) Kym Jenkins of the [Royal Australian and New Zealand College of Psychiatrists](/wiki/Royal_Australian_and_New_Zealand_College_of_Psychiatrists), in a [Sydney Morning Herald](/wiki/The_Sydney_Morning_Herald) article, said "people with mental illness are a more vulnerable group anyway for a variety of reasons. If you're feeling very anxious or very depressed ... you're automatically more vulnerable and you could be more susceptible to people advertising or marketing a quick fix. I do have concerns that people can be preyed upon when they are more vulnerable." [[24]](#cite_note-SydneyMorningHeraldmay2019-25). There is currently no [scientific evidence](/wiki/Scientific_evidence) to support positive health effect claims. [[4]](#cite_note-Derma2019-4) [[5]](#cite_note-TheGuardian2021-5) [[a]](#cite_note-longnote-7). However, most of the bioactive peptides so far characterized have displayed potential applications in medicine, such as phyllocaeruleins with hypotensive properties, tachykinins and phyllokinins opiate-like properties, and adenoregulins with antibiotic properties. [[25]](#cite_note-Nogueira_et_al-26) In a clinical trial of a randomized, placebo-controlled study in postoperative pain, dermorphin administered via the intrathecal route was "impressively superior" over the placebo and the reference compound morphine." [[26]](#cite_note-27) Due to the numerous biological activities of these substances and the similarities with the amino acid sequences related to mammalian neuropeptides and hormones, many have aroused the interest from a medical and pharmacological perspective, such as in the production of new drugs. [[25]](#cite_note-Nogueira_et_al-26) The [Australian Medical Association](/wiki/Australian_Medical_Association) supports the Australian [Therapeutic Goods Administrations](/wiki/Therapeutic_Goods_Administration) ban on the sale, supply, and use of kambo, saying it considers kambo to be In non-indigenous use, the frog secretion is described and marketed as a " [detox](/wiki/Detoxification_(alternative_medicine))" treatment, cleanse, [[18]](#cite_note-ABCnewsmarch2017-19) [[27]](#cite_note-NYT2021-28) purge, [[17]](#cite_note-SBSnov2019-18) and which is "good for everything". [[28]](#cite_note-Biotemas2011-29) Kambo has been marketed both as a "scientific" remedy, emphasizing the biochemistry, and as a "spiritual" remedy, emphasizing its indigenous origins. [[12]](#cite_note-LimaLabate2007-13) Purging (deliberate vomiting) has been a popular treatment since the 1800s. [[18]](#cite_note-ABCnewsmarch2017-19) "Detox" has been described by [Edzard Ernst](/wiki/Edzard_Ernst), emeritus professor of complementary medicine, as a term for [conventional medical treatments for addiction](/wiki/Drug_detoxification), which has been "hijacked by entrepreneurs, quacks, and charlatans to sell a bogus treatment." [[29]](#cite_note-TheGuardian2014-30) In Brazil, given the growth in the consumption of kambo in urban centers, there has been criticism by indigenous people, academics and communicators regarding the [cultural appropriation](/wiki/Cultural_appropriation) of indigenous knowledge, the process of extracting the secretion of the Phyllomedusa bicolor frog, the form of transmission of wisdom, and the price charged by the ritual and the mystification of the origin of the frog. [[12]](#cite_note-LimaLabate2007-13) There is also concern about [pharmacological](/wiki/Pharmacology) [patents](/wiki/Patent) on the peptides identified in kambo (see [biopiracy](/wiki/Biopiracy)), the commercialization of the kambo outside its place of origin, and the unknown impact on frog populations, since many more are now removed from their natural [habitats](/wiki/Habitat). [[28]](#cite_note-Biotemas2011-29) In light of the chemical complexity of the frog toxins, and their complex and potentially fatal effects, the authors of a 2022 review on the diagnosis and treatment of kambo cases said they urged "strict surveillance of the websites that encourage the use of this substance and [we] urge greater control of e-commerce or illicit trafficking of animals and secretions, including through the dark web". [[7]](#cite_note-SaccoZibettiBonetta2022-8) Environmental impact[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Kambo_(drug)&action=edit§ion=7)] The effect of the increased use of kambô rituals, and trafficking of the frogs and their secretions, may have an effect on the population of [Phyllomedusa bicolor](/wiki/Phyllomedusa_bicolor) in its natural [IUCN](/wiki/IUCN). [[30]](#cite_note-IUCN-31) Besides Phyllomedusa (species?), other threatened endemic frog species of South America's [neotropical](/wiki/Neotropical_realm) regions have been poached and smuggled on the market](/wiki/Black_market). - Phyllomedusa bicolor can spread parasites. [[31]](#cite_note-ParasitologyResearch2020-32) [Zoos](/wiki/Zoo) keep frogs for conservation purposes, and there are many parasites present in these animals that naturally occur only in the native habitats. [[31]](#cite_note-ParasitologyResearch2020-32) It is recommended for imported [amphibians](/wiki/Amphibians) to go through a [quarantine](/wiki/Quarantine) process to verify they are not spreading parasites that could damage other [ecosystems](/wiki/Ecosystem). [[31]](#cite_note-ParasitologyResearch2020-32) [Parasite](/wiki/Parasitism) infection rates in frogs is 51%, while in [salamanders](/wiki/Salamander) it is 13%. [[31]](#cite_note-ParasitologyResearch2020-32) Individuals who want to have them as pets are obligated and encouraged to get them examined to detect [gastrointestinal](/wiki/Gastrointestinal_tract) parasites that could potentially be harmful. [[31]](#cite_note-ParasitologyResearch2020-32) Neocosmocercella fisherae is the first [nematode](/wiki/Nematode) species found parasitising from the Brazilian Amazon Region. [[32]](#cite_note-SystematicParasitology2017-33) Notable deaths[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Kambo_(drug)&action=edit§ion=9)] A 40-year-old businessman was charged in Brazil in 2008 with the illegal exercise of medicine and [felony murder](/wiki/Felony_murder) after administering kambo toxins to a business colleague, who died; the deceased's son, who said his father had pressured him into participating, suffered more minor effects. [[33]](#cite_note-Estadao2008-34) [[14]](#cite_note-SilvaMonteiro2019-15) In Chile in 2009, Daniel Lara Aguilar, who suffered from chronic [lumbar disc disease](/wiki/Lumbar_disc_disease), died immediately after taking kambo administered by a local shaman in a mass healing ceremony; the autopsy was inconclusive due to preexisting conditions. [[15]](#cite_note-BBCMundo2016-16) [[34]](#cite_note-BioChile2009-35) The medical literature reported the 2018 case in Italy of a person with no known preexisting conditions besides obesity and ventricular hypertrophy, who, according to autopsy reports, died of [cardiac arrhythmia](/wiki/Cardiac_arrhythmia) while under the effects of kambo use. [[35]](#cite_note-Forensic2018-36) [[14]](#cite_note-SilvaMonteiro2019-15) In March 2019, kambo practitioner Natasha Lechner suffered a cardiac arrest and died while receiving kambo. [[17]](#cite_note-SBSnov2019-18) [[36]](#cite_note-ABCNewsmarch2019-37) [[6]](#cite_note-ABCNewsMay2023-6) In April 2019, a homicide investigation was opened into the death by "severe [cerebral edema](/wiki/Cerebral_edema)" of a young person who had taken kambo toxins in Chile; the import of the frog and its secretions is illegal in Chile. [[16]](#cite_note-LaNancion2019-17) [[37]](#cite_note-Infocatolica2019-38) In October 2021, Australian man Jarred Antonovich died at a festival in New South Wales from a perforated oesophagus suspected to be caused by excessive vomiting after being administered kambo and n,n-dimethyltriptamine. After a car accident in 1997 from which he had to learn to walk and talk again, he was left with lasting impediments, the inquest heard, which may have contributed to the esophageal rupture. [[38]](#cite_note-39) Pharmacology[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Kambo_(drug)&action=edit§ion=10)] The frog secretes a range of small chemical compounds of a type called [peptides](/wiki/Peptide), which have several different effects. [[39]](#cite_note-ChangPorreca2003-40) Peptides found in the frog secretions include the [dermorphin](/wiki/Dermorphin) such phyllokinin, [caerulein](/wiki/Caerulein), and adrenoregulin are also present. [[39]](#cite_note-ChangPorreca2003-40) There is active medical research into the peptides found in the skin secretions of Phyllomedusa bicolor, focusing on discovering their biological effects. There have been some preclinical trials in mice and rats, but no [phase-1](/wiki/Phases_of_clinical_research) tests or [clinical trials](/wiki/Clinical_trials) of safety in humans, as November 2019 below [Australian] Therepeutic Goods Administration (TGA). ["Consultation: Proposed amendments to the Poisons Standard - ACMS, ACCS and Joint ACMS/ACCS meetings, March 2021"](https://www.tga.gov.au/resources/consultation/consultation-proposed-amendments-poisons-standard-acms-accs-and-joint-acmsaccs-meetings-march-2021). "Kambo use in the absence of medically trained supervision represents a significant health risk, especially for people with cardiovascular disease due to the significant cardiovascular effects. Although rare, deaths have also been reported from kambo use. The significant adverse effects from the topical application of kambo to scarified or burnt areas of skin include: nausea vomiting oesophageal rupture diarrhoea stomach pain liver damage burning sensation lowered blood pressure (hypotension) increased heart rate (tachycardia) These effects are seen as part of the spiritual purification/healing process, however, there is no clinical evidence of kambo having any beneficial medical effect. Onset of clinical signs and symptoms is rapid, and there have been reports of altered mental state, agitation, paranoia, delusions and general psychosis. There is insufficient information to characterise the risk from long-term repeated use of kambo." [Australian Medical Association](/wiki/Australian_Medical_Association)(March 2021). ["Australian Medical Association Submission to the Therapeutic Goods Administration - Proposed amendments to the Poisons Standard"](https://web.archive.org/web/20211006050132/https://www.ama.com.au/sites/default/files/2021-02/AMA%20submission%20to%20the%20TGA%20-%20proposed%20amendments%20to%20the%20Poisons%20Standard%20-%20March%202021%20proposals%20-%20FINAL.pdf)(PDF). p. 3. Archived from [the original](https://www.ama.com.au/sites/default/files/2021-02/AMA%20submission%20to%20the%20TGA%20-%20proposed%20amendments%20to%20the%20Poisons%20Standard%20-%20March%202021%20proposals%20-%20FINAL.pdf)(PDF) on 2021-10-06. "The AMA supports the proposal to include a new Schedule 9 entry for Kambo. The AMA considers kambo to be a significant health risk for those who use it. In addition to its harmful effects both intended and adverse, the act of blistering the skin and applying kambo to the burnt area risks other health concerns such as infection. There is also a risk that using kambo would prevent a patient from seeing a medical practitioner for their medical condition and delay diagnosis. Kambo should be regulated under the Poisons Standard as it appears to be used as a therapeutic product by 'kambo practitioners'. [[21]](#cite_note-ABCNewssept2018-22)There is currently insufficient evidence for its intended therapeutic effects."
